title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to allow certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans. The "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. This provision ensures that participants do not incur a break in service with the employer for the purpose of determining benefit nonforfeitability. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer for benefit determination purposes. Earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liabilities and obligations of the plan. In a multiemployer plan, liabilities are allocated as specified by the plan sponsor. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The period of participation extends from the qualifying event date to the earliest of reaching normal retirement age, employer ceasing to provide the plan, or failure to pay contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue accruing benefits in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Qualified beneficiaries must fund any obligations of the plan, including employer contributions and mandatory employee contributions, if benefits cease due to failure to pay required contributions. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive employer and employee contributions in the same manner as other beneficiaries. Benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions are only provided if available before the qualifying event. Participants are deemed to have received compensation at the rate prior to the occurrence. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive contributions at the rate prior to the qualifying event. Contributions by the beneficiary are limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution and can be made in monthly installments. No contribution can be required before 45 days after the initial election for continued participation. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving contributions at the previous rate, with a limit of 102 percent of the applicable contribution. Contributions can be made in monthly installments, with no requirement for contribution before 45 days after the initial election. The election period must begin before benefits accrual would cease and last for at least 90 days. Any qualified beneficiary's election for continued participation also includes other beneficiaries who would otherwise cease to be covered. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue receiving contributions at the previous rate, with a limit of 102 percent of the applicable contribution. The act does not apply to defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. Definitions include applicable contribution and qualified beneficiary. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue receiving contributions after a qualifying event, such as termination or reduction of employment hours, within seven years of normal retirement age. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue receiving contributions after a qualifying event, such as termination or reduction of employment hours, within seven years of normal retirement age. The Act applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996, with a special rule for defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements, exempting plan years before the termination of agreements or January 1, 2000.
